title: Synthetic Recap
body:
**Knicks Ride Ewing's Historic Night to Dismantle Celtics at MSG**

NEW YORK – On a night where the Madison Square Garden rafters seemed to hang a little lower, Patrick Ewing delivered a performance for the ages, single-handedly powering the New York Knicks to a decisive 98-82 victory over the rival Boston Celtics in 1998.

This was not merely a win; it was a coronation. Ewing, the franchise cornerstone, was utterly dominant, pouring in a career-high and Garden-shaking **44 points**. From the opening tip, he established an unstoppable rhythm in the paint, turning every entry pass into a guaranteed two points against a helpless Celtics defense. He was a force of nature, and the game’s narrative belonged to him alone.

While Ewing’s scoring was a historic spectacle, his supporting cast provided the necessary grit. Allan Houston added 18 points, but the night belonged to the man in the middle. The Knicks' defense, energized by Ewing’s dominance on the other end, smothered the Celtics, holding them to a paltry 82 points.

Boston, overwhelmed by the Ewing onslaught, had no answer. Their efforts were scattered, with no player able to muster a counter-punch against the Knicks’ titan. The game was effectively a one-man show, with Ewing as the star, director, and producer.

When the final buzzer sounded, the scoreboard told the story of a solid team victory. But the lasting memory, the one etched into the legacy of the fabled arena, was of Patrick Ewing’s 44 points—a masterclass and a monumental individual achievement that lifted his team to a commanding win. It was a night that reminded everyone why he was, and forever will be, a New York legend.
